title: Scottish court ruling: what happens next in prorogation dispute
text:
In the immediate aftermath of the Scottish appeal court unanimously ruling that Boris Johnson has suspended parliament unlawfully, fresh legal disputes erupted over what will happen next.

What has the Scottish court said?

Only a summary of its judgment has been released so far but it is strongly worded. The statement ends with the words: “Accordingly the court will make an order declaring that the prime minister’s advice to HM the Queen and the prorogation which followed thereon was unlawful and is thus null and of no effect.” There is no mention of any delay until next Tuesday when the supreme court is due to hear further appeals in the case.

Brexit: Labour and SNP demand recall of parliament after Scottish court rules prorogation unlawful - live news Read more

Can MPs return to the Commons and resume their debates?

Jolyon Maugham QC, the barrister who masterminded the Edinburgh court challenge, argued that since the government had not applied to delay the effect of the ruling, parliament is no longer suspended. If the government wants to delay prorogation further, he maintained, ministers would have to make a fresh application at a UK court immediately to resuspend parliamentary sittings.

The government and many Westminster politicians, however, appear to be taking the line that MPs should wait until the supreme court has had its final say after next week. A spokeswoman for the Speaker, John Bercow, and the House of Commons authorities said it would be up to the prime minister to recall parliament during prorogation. “Any decision to accelerate the meeting of parliament during prorogation is a matter for the government,” she said.

When does the case return to court?

If the government does not feel the need to make an emergency application to suspend the effect of the Scottish court ruling, the next scheduled judgment is due to be delivered in Belfast on Thursday when high court judges will give their ruling on a similar challenge to the prime minister’s proroguing of parliament. Whichever way that goes, there could then be a further and speedy appeal to Northern Ireland’s appeal court, which could involve judges sitting at the weekend.

When does the supreme court intervene?

The UK’s highest court has arranged a three-day hearing starting on 17 September to join together all three appeals from the legal challenges in Edinburgh, Belfast and London. The Northern Ireland claims are partially being fought on separate grounds, relying on the 1998 Northern Ireland Act, which gave legal effect to the Good Friday agreement, which formally ended the Troubles.
description: Fresh legal battles erupt after judges say Johnson suspended parliament unlawfully
